headline: Morning Headlines: Cleveland moves to expunge 4,000 low-level marijuana offenses...and more stories
author: Amy Eddings
sentences:
Here are your morning headlines for Thursday, April 7th:
Cleveland moves to expunge 4,000 low-level marijuana offenses
Republican U.S. Rep. Bob Gibbs abruptly retires
Ohio Chamber of Commerce has concerns with bills banning “divisive” subjects
Ohio lawmakers set aside $85 million for Intel project
Guardians debut in the season opener against KC
Weather: sunny early, rainy later
Cleveland moves to expunge 4,000 low-level marijuana offenses
(Ideastream Public Media) – The City of Cleveland is seeking to wipe out more than 4,000 low-level marijuana violations.

Ohio Chamber of Commerce has concerns with bills banning “divisive” subjects
(Cleveland.com) – The head of the Ohio Chamber of Commerce said the business group has concerns about a bill to limit or ban classroom discussion of “divisive” subjects, including racism, sexual orientation, and gender identity.

The city compiled the records after its law director noticed that more than 400 people had been charged with misdemeanor marijuana offenses since 2020, the year that the city council voted to decriminalize low-level pot violations.

Guardians debut in the season opener against KC
(MLB.com) -- The Cleveland Guardians make their debut in their Major League Baseball season opener this afternoon against the Royals in Kansas City.

Ohio lawmakers set aside $85 million for Intel project
(Cleveland.com) – Ohio’s General Assembly has approved spending $85 million on development costs for an Intel factory planned near Columbus.
In a statement, Chamber CEO Steve Stivers said some of the language of House Bill 616 “may impede Ohio’s ability to lure the best and brightest minds” to work for businesses in the state.

Republican U.S. Rep. Bob Gibbs abruptly retires
(Ideastream Public Media) -- In a surprise move, Republican U.S. Rep. Bob Gibbs announced he's retiring, after six terms in office.
The state has committed to spending more than $2 billion in grants, infrastructure improvements, and tax credits as part of its deal with Intel.
He noted the state’s recent success in securing a commitment from Intel to build a $20 billion semiconductor chip factory near Columbus.
The current new Congressional map drew Gibbs into a primary with Max Miller, a former aide in the Trump White House.
In a statement on social media, Gibbs said he is a victim of Ohio's bogged-down redistricting process.
Mayor Justin Bibb said it's part of his effort to take a holistic approach to criminal justice reform.
Gibbs called Ohio’s redistricting fight a “circus.” Early voting for the May primary began this week.

Weather: sunny early, rainy later
(National Weather Service) – Plenty of sunshine to start the day.
Miller originally set out to challenge Anthony Gonzalez, who is also retiring from Congress.
It will gradually turn cloudy, with a 40 percent chance of afternoon showers.
The Ohio Senate added the appropriation to an unrelated agricultural bill.
The Ohio House of Representatives approved the change shortly afterward.
Righty Shane Bieber gets his third consecutive Opening Day start.
Right-hander Zack Greinke takes the mound for the Royals.
First pitch is 4:10 p.m. at Kauffman Stadium.
The legislation now goes to Ohio Gov.
Tonight, showers linger until 9 p.m.
High 58 in Akron, 56 in Cleveland.
Mike DeWine for his signature.
Partly cloudy, low 39.
